intro: Phaca patagonica, commonly known as the Patagonian phaca, is a flowering plant native to the southern regions of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in grasslands and along riverbanks. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
